projects.title: Labyrinth
projects.intro: a two-player asymmetric hide-and-seek game set in a dark maze. One player becomes the Hider (a living person trying to escape), while the other becomes the Seeker (a ghostly entity that hunts through sound)

details.description: Labyrinth is an asymmetric two-player game about perception. Player 1 navigates a maze using Leap Motion (Arduino-driven light input that reveals a cone of vision in-game). Player 2 cannot see the maze; instead, they track the hider through spatialized foodstep audio, inspired by echolocation. The tension comes from incomplete, unequal senses—light versus echo.

inspiration: Asymmetric multiplayer (hunter vs. hider) dynamics
Dark Echo-style echolocation aesthetics
Embodied interfaces for sensory substitution
development: Built Arduino ‘torch’ with adjustable brightness mapped to a Unity spotlight
Implemented spatialized audio cues and decay to suggest distance
Designed mazes balancing fairness for both roles
Ran playtests to tune loudness, reveal radius, and movement speed
images: Iterated on HUD minimalism to heighten tension
Refined echo cooldown and reverb tails for readability
Optimized performance for stable latency between Arduino and Unity

projects.title: Spinphony
projects.intro: A record-player-inspired platformer where a lost note (Do) spins through musical puzzles to reunite with its scale.

details.description: Spinphony is a playful platformer controlled by a custom record-like controller. Rotating the physical ‘record’ moves the character through a world of rhythmic platforms, while two arcade buttons trigger jumps and interactions. Built in Unity with an Arduino-based rotary encoder + buttons, the game explores embodied interaction—turning music and motion into level design.

inspiration: Pinball mechanics and Galton-board probability as level rhythm
Cooling system aesthetics of quantum computers for visual language
Embodied music interaction: turning rotation into movement
development: Prototyped record-style controller with rotary encoder and two buttons
Implemented Unity C# serial bridge for real-time input
Designed levels around tempo, momentum, and rotational inertia
Iterated on difficulty curve based on playtests
images: Polished game feel (acceleration, coyote time, audio cues)

projects.title: Chester Choiceworth
projects.intro: "You don't choose your lifestyle, Data does."

details.description:
Chester Choiceworth is an interactive installation that turns your spending habits into a visual and playful experience.

By uploading your monthly transaction record, the system creates a digital receipt summarizing your expenses and maps out where you’ve spent your money. At the same time, a receipt printer prints out exaggerated ads for luxury or budget items based on your spending level, highlighting how consumer targeting shapes our lifestyle.

inspiration: Studied behavioral psychology and decision-making patterns
Analyzed existing lifestyle tracking applications
Conducted user interviews about daily decision-making processes
development: Built Arduino sensors for data collection

projects.title: Funguide
projects.intro: A web app that uses AI to identify mushroom species from images and generates unique recipes. Built with Gemini API and React.

details.description: Funguide is a mushroom recognition and recipe generator. Simply upload a photo of a mushroom, and the system will identify it, providing basic information along with a recipe featuring that mushroom.

inspiration: Problems:

* lack of instant mushroom identifier app (iNaturist, Plantiary)
* Combine recipe function together (where my interest in mushroom comes from)
* can’t get instant knowledge while out foraging it.
Idea:

* image recognition
* recipe generator.
development: Built Arduino sensors for data collection
